description: From Middle English, from Old French dispenser, from Latin dispēnsāre (“to weigh out, pay out, distribute, regulate, manage, control, dispense”), frequentative of dispendere (“to weigh out”), from dis- (“apart”) + pendere (“to weigh”).

verbs.description: dispense (third-person singular simple present dispenses, present participle dispensing, simple past and past participle dispensed)

entries.meaning: To issue, distribute, or give out.
examples: The smoky spray seemed to trap whatever light there was and to dispense it subtly.

entries.meaning: To apply, as laws to particular cases; to administer; to execute; to manage; to direct.
To supply or make up a medicine or prescription.
(obsolete) To give a dispensation to (someone); to excuse.
examples: He appeared to think himself born to be supported by others, and dispensed from all necessity of providing for himself.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To compensate; to make up; to make amends.
examples: His synne was dispensed with golde, wherof it was compensed
